title: What is HTML
description: HTML, which stands for HyperText Markup Language, is the standard language used to create and structure content on the web. It provides the basic building blocks for web pages by defining elements like headings, paragraphs, links, images, and more. HTML uses a series of tags and attributes to structure text, images, and other content types, making it possible for web browsers to display content as intended.

title: Document Structure
description:
In HTML, a document structure follows a specific layout to ensure that browsers can correctly interpret and display the content. Here is the typical structure of an HTML document: 

1. Doctype Declaration 
Every HTML document starts with a <!DOCTYPE html> declaration. This tells the browser that the document is written in HTML5 (the latest HTML version).
<!DOCTYPE html>

2. HTML Element 
The <html> element wraps all the content of the HTML document. It has two main child elements: <head> and <body>.
<html lang="en">

3. Head Section 
The <head> section contains metadata about the document, which isn’t visible on the webpage but is used by browsers and search engines. 
Common elements within <head> include: 
• Title: Defines the title shown in the browser tab. 
• Meta Tags: Provide information about the document, such as character encoding, author, and description. 
• Link Tags: Link external resources like stylesheets or icons. 
• Script Tags: Link to JavaScript files or contain inline JavaScript.

<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Document Title</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>

4. Body Section 
The <body> section contains the visible content of the web page, such as text, images, videos, and links. 
This is where you place HTML elements that define the structure and content of the page, including headings, paragraphs, images, lists, and tables.

Welcome to My Website

This is a sample paragraph.

Visit Example.com

5. Closing HTML Tag 
The </html> tag closes the entire HTML document.
</html>

title: Attributes
description: Attributes in HTML provide additional information about elements, helping control their behavior, appearance, or content. They are written inside the opening tag of an element, usually in name-value pairs. Here’s an overview of some common HTML attributes and their uses:

1. Basic Attributes 
id: Uniquely identifies an element within the document. Useful for styling with CSS and targeting with JavaScript.
Header Content
class: Groups elements together, allowing them to be styled as a unit or targeted with JavaScript.

2. Content-Specific Attributes src: Specifies the source file for media elements like ,
alt: Provides alternative text for images if they can’t load; also important for accessibility.
href: Specifies the URL for links in <a> elements or links to external stylesheets in <link> tags.
Visit Example

3. Style and Layout Attributes 
style: Defines inline CSS styles for an element
Styled text
width and height: Sets dimensions, usually for media elements like ,

4. Form Attributes 
type: Specifies the type of input, such as text, password, checkbox, radio, etc.
<input type="text" name="username">
name: Identifies form data fields, which are sent to the server.
<input type="email" name="email">
placeholder: Displays placeholder text within a form field until the user enters input.
<input type="text" placeholder="Enter your name">
value: Specifies the default value for form elements like <input>.
<input type="text" value="Default Text">
maxlength and minlength: Set the maximum and minimum number of characters allowed in a form field.
<input type="text" maxlength="10">
required: Makes form fields mandatory before submission.
<input type="email" required>

5. Event Attributes 
Used to define event handling for actions like clicks, hovers, and keyboard input. onclick: Triggered when an element is clicked.
<button onclick="alert('Button clicked!')">Click Me</button>
onmouseover: Triggered when the user hovers over an element.

6. Accessibility Attributes 
alt: Adds descriptive text for images, helping screen readers describe images to visually impaired users. 
aria-*: A set of attributes for improving accessibility (e.g., aria-label, aria-hidden, aria-controls).
<button aria-label="Close Menu">×</button>
role: Specifies the role of an element to assistive technologies.
<nav role="navigation">Navigation Links</nav>

7. Global Attributes 
Can be used on almost any HTML element. 
title: Provides additional information as a tooltip when hovering over the element.
<abbr title="HyperText Markup Language">HTML</abbr>
lang: Specifies the language of the element’s content, useful for accessibility

title: Elements
description: In HTML, elements are the individual components that make up a webpage. Each element is represented by tags and defines a part of the document, such as text, images, links, or lists. Here are some essential HTML elements:

1. Structural Elements 
• <html>: The root element of an HTML document. 
• <head>: Contains meta information about the document, like the title and links to stylesheets. 
• <title>: Sets the title of the webpage, displayed on the browser tab. 
• <body>: Contains the main content of the document that will be visible to users.

2. Text Elements •

is the smallest. •

3. Formatting Elements 
• <b> or <strong>: Makes text bold. <strong> also adds semantic importance. 
• <i> or <em>: Italicizes text. <em> adds emphasis with semantic meaning. 
• <u>: Underlines text (though it’s generally discouraged as it can be mistaken for a link). 
• <small>: Displays smaller-sized text. 
• <mark>: Highlights text. 
• <del> - Deleted text 
• <ins> - Inserted text 
• <sub> - Subscript text 
• <sup> - Superscript text

4. Link and Media Elements • : Anchor tag used to create hyperlinks. The href attribute specifies the URL. • : Embeds an image. The src attribute specifies the image file, and alt provides alternative text. •

5. List Elements 
• <ul>: Unordered list, usually displayed with bullet points. 
• <ol>: Ordered list, typically displayed with numbers. 
• <li>: List item, used within <ul> or <ol> to define each list item.

6. Table Elements 
• <table>: Creates a table. 
• <tr>: Table row, used to create rows within a table. 
• <th>: Table header, typically displayed in bold within the table row. 
• <td>: Table data cell, used to add data within a row.

7. Form Elements 
• <form>: Creates a form for user input. 
• <input>: Defines an input field, with various types like text, radio, checkbox, etc. 
• <textarea>: Creates a multi-line text input. 
• <button>: Creates a clickable button. 
• <label>: Labels an input for accessibility.

8. Semantic Elements 
• <header>: Represents the introductory content or a navigational section. 
• <nav>: Defines a navigation section. 
• <main>: Represents the main content of the document. 
• <section>: Defines a section of the document. 
• <article>: Defines a piece of content, like a blog post. 
• <footer>: Represents the footer section of the document.

9. Container Elements 
• <div>: Generic container element used for layout and styling. 
• <span>: Inline container used to style or manipulate a specific piece of text within a line.
